description:
Thermoascus crustaceus is a species of thermophilic (heat-loving) fungus belonging to the phylum Ascomycota. It is known to thrive in high-temperature environments, with an optimal growth temperature ranging from 45°C to 55°C.

This fungus is characterized by the production of ascomata, which are the fruiting bodies that contain the sexual spores. The ascomata of T. crustaceus are typically spherical or subglobose in shape and have a crusty or crustose appearance, hence the specific epithet "crustaceus."

T. crustaceus is known to produce a variety of extracellular enzymes, including cellulases, hemicellulases, and xylanases, which allow it to efficiently degrade lignocellulosic biomass. This property makes the fungus a potential candidate for applications in biofuel production, bioconversion of agricultural waste, and other industrial processes that involve the utilization of plant-derived materials.

Additionally, T. crustaceus has been reported to exhibit antimicrobial and antioxidant activities, suggesting its potential use in the development of novel pharmaceutical or biotechnological products.
